Text: Chief Rabbinate officially recognizes Ethiopian Jews https://t.co/iFiq8WzMEy
IHRA_Explanation: The tweet does not exhibit any characteristics of antisemitism as defined by IHRA. It reports on an official recognition by the Chief Rabbinate of Ethiopian Jews, which is a welcoming and inclusive act within the Jewish community. There are no hateful or stereotypical elements, nor any accusations or denials that align with antisemitic behavior.
JDA_Explanation: The tweet in question, "Chief Rabbinate officially recognizes Ethiopian Jews," does not exhibit any characteristics of antisemitism as defined by the JDA. It merely reports a positive development regarding the recognition of Jewish identity within the community of Ethiopian Jews. There is no discrimination, prejudice, hostility, or violence against Jews as Jews, nor does it involve any coded or indirect attacks on Jewish people. The content is neutral and factual, celebrating an inclusive aspect of Jewish identity. Therefore, this tweet does not violate the JDA's definition of antisemitism.

Text: jews have been on the frontlines of movements for justice forever bc fighting for a more just world is what we do. that is literally the whole purpose of judaism. but when we‚Äôre experiencing the greatest rise in antisemitism in decades no one cares but us
IHRA_Explanation: The tweet implies that only Jewish people are concerned about the rise in antisemitism, suggesting a subtle form of blaming Jews for not being part of the broader community's concerns. This aligns with IHRA's examples where accusing Jews as a collective can be seen as reinforcing negative stereotypes or implying responsibility for societal issues. Thus, it qualifies as antisemitic under the provided definition.
JDA_Explanation: The tweet does not exhibit antisemitism as per the JDA guidelines. It expresses concern about rising antisemitism without any negative stereotypes, hostile language, or discrimination against Jews. Instead, it highlights the Jewish community's role in justice movements and their awareness of the issue, aligning with protected political speech and criticism without the intent to harm or discriminate.

Text: It‚Äôs true that Jews were not coded as white in Europe, very much the opposite. And that our white privilege in the US is conditional. \n\nAND it‚Äôs also true that in the US, built as it is (literally) on antiblackness, I am seen as white & afforded the protections of whiteness in + https://t.co/iYQzwlvgSZ
IHRA_Explanation: The tweet discusses systemic issues related to race in the United States, specifically about anti-Blackness shaping societal structures that afford white privilege. It mentions Jews not being coded as white in Europe but now seen as white in the U.S., highlighting conditional white privilege. While it addresses race and systemic issues, it does not specifically target Jews with negative stereotypes or accusations commonly associated with antisemitism. The focus is on broader societal structures rather than Jewish-specific conspiracies or negativity.
JDA_Explanation: The tweet does not exhibit antisemitism according to the JDA definition. While it discusses racial identity and systemic benefits, it doesn't apply classical antisemitic stereotypes or imply Jewish control over resources or hidden power. Instead, it addresses race and identity within a historical context without targeting Jews as a group or promoting harmful conspiracies.

Text: @BigTimeIdiot1 @BlackShadow998 @JuliaHB1 They have a higher suicide rate than Jews in 1930's Germany and African slaves in the 1700's. Didn't realise trans people in western democracies in 2020 had it worse than those folk. My bad!
IHRA_Explanation: The tweet compares the struggles of trans people in Western democracies to those of Jews during the Holocaust and African slaves, drawing parallels that could trivialize the Holocaust and equate Jewish suffering with other forms of oppression. This comparison might inadvertently reinforce antisemitic narratives by conflating distinct historical contexts and could be seen as making inappropriate or harmful associations, aligning with IHRA's definition of antisemitism through stereotypical or mendacious comparisons.
JDA_Explanation: The tweet compares trans people's struggles to the persecution faced by Jews in 1930s Germany and African slaves. While sensitive due to historical context, it doesn't target Jews directly but uses their suffering as a reference point for another group. There is no explicit antisemitic content, nor does it attack Jews based on their identity. Therefore, according to the JDA definition, this tweet isn't considered antisemitic.

Text: ‚ÄúIsrael, the world‚Äôs only Jewish state, was not established for just one type of Jew but for all Jews, from every part of the world. No matter where Jews physically reside, they maintain a connection to the land of Israel‚Äù \n\nhttps://t.co/Bk8P3VWCew
IHRA_Explanation: The tweet does not explicitly contain any content that meets the IHRA definition of antisemitism. It asserts the connection of Jews to Israel without expressing hatred, using harmful stereotypes, or denying historical facts. While it might be interpreted as promoting a specific Jewish identity, it doesn't cross into the realm of antisemitic rhetoric as defined by IHRA.
JDA_Explanation: The tweet asserts that Israel was established for all Jews worldwide and emphasizes their inherent connection to the land. This broad statement essentializes Jews by suggesting an unavoidable link to Israel, which aligns with antisemitic tropes of collective Jewish identity tied to a specific geographic entity. It generalizes negatively about all Jews, falling under the JDA's criteria for antisemitism by promoting sweeping negative generalizations and reinforcing stereotypes.

Text: @AniMaikaru @Salamomoutro @SirDemiface All I'm reading is that you think jews are goblins.
IHRA_Explanation: The tweet uses the term "jews" in a derogatory context by referring to them as "goblins," which is a stereotype that demeans Jewish individuals. This aligns with IHRA's definition of antisemitism, where such language can be seen as targeting Jewish people with negative stereotypes, falling under manifestations of antisemitism.
JDA_Explanation: The tweet uses the term "goblins" to refer to Jews, which associates them with negative, dehumanizing stereotypes. This directly targets Jewish identity with a pejorative comparison, falling under verbal antisemitism as defined by the JDA guidelines.

Text: Lengthy thread- take a few minutes to read the whole thing.\n‚ÄúJews of Russian empire suffered from a lot - abuse, tortures, forced conversion, pogroms and from institutional exploitation of Jewish men by Russian Imperial Army.‚Äù https://t.co/eXaHEO8cxl
IHRA_Explanation: The tweet describes historical events and accusations that align with antisemitic tropes by targeting Jews collectively for alleged misdeeds or exploitation, which fits the IHRA definition of antisemitism.
JDA_Explanation: The tweet discusses historical suffering of Jews under the Russian Empire, including abuse, forced conversion, pogroms, and institutional exploitation by the Russian Imperial Army. While these events are distressing and involve anti-Jewish actions, the tweet does not promote discrimination against Jews as a group or reflect antisemitic hostility in its current form. It is a statement about historical persecution, which, while tragic, does not align with the definition of antisemitism as provided by the JDA. The content is factual without promoting or endorsing discriminatory views toward Jews.

Text: @stardales Also don't forget that many older Jews feared the Iran deals effect on Israel, plus the fact that Mehdi drew the "He voted for Iraq" card when it's just you know.
IHRA_Explanation: The tweet discusses concerns about policy impacts on Israel and references a political argument without targeting Jews as a collective or using harmful stereotypes. It does not meet the criteria outlined in the IHRA definition of antisemitism.
JDA_Explanation: The tweet references Mehdi's voting card as a Jewish individual involved in actions (voting for Iraq) that might negatively impact Israel. This implies a connection between Mehdi's Jewish identity and perceived negative outcomes for Israel, aligning with classical antisemitic tropes of Jews exerting undue influence. guideline B.6 applies here, as it involves applying stereotypes to Israel by linking a Jew's actions to negative consequences. Therefore, the tweet is deemed antisemitic under the JDA.

Text: Jews have endured for thousands of years and multiple attempts to annihilate us. We know about affliction. We know about the banality of evil. We will celebrate our resilience this #Passover, separated from each other, but with our principles of family and tradition intact.
IHRA_Explanation: The tweet does not exhibit antisemitic characteristics as per the IHRA definition. It acknowledges historical Jewish suffering without making mendacious or stereotypical allegations, nor does it target Jews collectively with harmful stereotypes or false accusations. Instead, it reflects on resilience and celebrates cultural values, consistent with a positive and inclusive stance.
JDA_Explanation: The tweet does not exhibit any elements of antisemitism as defined by the Jerusalem Declaration on Antisemitism. It reflects historical awareness without promoting discrimination or hostility against Jews, instead focusing on resilience and cultural celebration.

Text: For I tell you that Christ (the Messiah) became a servant and a minister to the circumcised (the Jews) in order to show God's truthfulness and hone.. ROM 15:8 https://t.co/SSlKed8iQe
IHRA_Explanation: The tweet references Romans 15:8, discussing how Christ served the circumcised (Jews) to bring God's truth. While it mentions Jews in a religious context, it does not contain any hateful or stereotypical language, nor does it blame Jews for wrongdoing, deny the Holocaust, use antisemitic stereotypes, or target Jewish collectivities negatively. Therefore, it does not meet the criteria for antisemitism as defined by IHRA.
JDA_Explanation: The tweet references Romans 15:8, which discusses serving circumcised Jews (Jews), linking Christ's role to them. This can reinforce classical antisemitic stereotypes about Jews being a distinct group with special significance, potentially playing into harmful notions of Jewish superiority or control. By invoking this verse, the tweet may target Jews collectively, aligning with JDA guidelines that identify such content as antisemitic. Thus, it violates the principle of equal treatment for all and contributes to harmful stereotypes.

Text: The use of the police this way against the Jews in New York is shocking and completely out of control.¬† And let‚Äôs all take note: this is being done at the direction of a liberal Democrat Governor. https://t.co/643hy9E1wr
IHRA_Explanation: The tweet does not exhibit antisemitic characteristics under the IHRA definition. It critiques a specific instance where Jews are being targeted by police and notes the involvement of a Democrat Governor, which is a factual statement rather than an expression of antisemitism. There's no indication of blaming Jews collectively or using stereotypes associated with antisemitism. The content focuses on the situation in New York without generalizing to all Jews or implying any negative stereotype about them.
JDA_Explanation: The tweet does not conform to antisemitic behavior as defined by the JDA. It expresses concern about a specific instance of police action against Jews in New York, attributed to a political figure, but it doesn't employ racialization or classical antisemitic stereotypes. While the criticism may be one-sided, it is based on an evidence-based critique of a particular event rather than any generalized negative perception of Jews as a group. Therefore, it does not meet the criteria for antisemitism under the JDA guidelines.

Text: Vienna Judenplatz memorial to 65,000 Austrian Jews murdered in the Holocaust, by Rachel Whiteread. The outside surface is cast library shelves turned inside out, spines of the books facing inwards, not visible, unknown like the lives the people killed #womensart #WorldBookDay https://t.co/I5SCC9qTFE
IHRA_Explanation: The tweet respectfully remembers the victims of the Holocaust by acknowledging their suffering through an artistic memorial. It does not contain any content that aligns with antisemitic behaviors as defined by IHRA, such as blaming Jews for conspiracies or denying the Holocaust. Instead, it focuses on honoring memory without targeting Jewish people or communities. The hashtags used are unrelated and do not contribute to antisemitic themes.
JDA_Explanation: The tweet does not exhibit antisemitism as it neither uses nor promotes negative stereotypes about Jews nor does it discriminate against them. Instead, it acknowledges the Holocaust victims in a respectful manner without linking them to harmful stereotypes or conspiracy theories. The focus is on commemorating a tragic historical event rather than targeting Jewish people.

Text: In the national survey, 63 percent of US adults between 18 and 39 years old did not know that 6 million Jews were killed during the Holocaust. https://t.co/HbmMbTU3oy
IHRA_Explanation: The tweet reports a survey result indicating that 63% of young US adults are unaware of the Holocaust's specific statistic. While this highlights a lack of knowledge, it does not express hate or use antisemitic stereotypes. It merely presents information about educational gaps without implying blame or conspiracy, thus not fitting the IHRA definition of antisemitism.
JDA_Explanation: The tweet reports that 63% of young US adults are unaware of the Holocaust's scale, specifically the death toll of 6 million Jews. While it presents a factual survey result, this information can be interpreted as implying or contributing to the denial or minimization of the Holocaust, which aligns with antisemitic behavior as defined by the JDA. Therefore, the tweet is considered antisemitic.

Text:
Over 450 young British Jews have written to @BoardofDeputies to urged them to speak up against annexation

We‚Äôre not being listened to

Please amplify our voices by sharing this video and signing our open letter
https://t.co/WigfV28WwC

We need to talk about annexation https://t.co/NpIthXRRlA
IHRA_Explanation: The tweet discusses political opposition to Israel's annexation policies and advocates for greater attention to the issue without targeting Jews or promoting harmful stereotypes. It does not align with IHRA's definition of antisemitism, which involves specific discriminatory actions or beliefs rather than generalized criticism of a policy.
JDA_Explanation: The tweet is about young British Jews advocating against annexation by urging their leaders to speak out. It‚Äôs a political expression aimed at influencing policy, not targeting Jews as a group. There are no antisemitic elements like stereotypes or attacks on Jewish identity.

Text: The model of the entire class is ‚ÄúSee this footage of Jews being loaded into cattle cars? Here‚Äôs footage of German POWs being sent to Siberia. Pretty similar, huh?‚Äù
IHRA_Explanation: The tweet compares the Holocaust, a genocide targeting Jews, with the treatment of German prisoners of war. This comparison equates Jewish suffering with that of non-Jews, aligning with IHRA's definition of antisemitism, as it uses historical atrocities to dehumanize or negatively stereotype Jews.
JDA_Explanation: The tweet compares footage of Jews being loaded into cattle cars during the Holocaust to German POWs in Siberia. This comparison equates two distinct atrocities, but the specific mention of Jews being targeted during the Holocaust directly references antisemitic historical events. By juxtaposing this with POWs, it risks trivializing the Holocaust and reinforcing a false equivalence that could incite hostility or prejudice against Jewish people. The use of such sensitive historical material in a comparison can be seen as an attempt to diminish the uniqueness of the Holocaust or imply a broader conspiracy narrative, both of which align with antisemitic themes. Thus, this tweet adheres to the JDA's definition of antisemitism by invoking harmful stereotypes and comparisons that target Jews.

Text: About the Bani Nadir Jews, Quran says that #God struck the enemies a blow from where they didn‚Äôt expect it.\nThe same happened in the Air Force Commanders pledging allegiance with Imam, & believers were empowered from where they didn‚Äôt expect it. This is ‚Äúunexpected provision.‚Äù
IHRA_Explanation: The tweet references Jews and uses Quranic verses to discuss divine intervention, which can be interpreted as implying that Jews are responsible for or benefit from unexpected successes against enemies. While it doesn't explicitly accuse Jews of conspiracies or harmful actions, the context of religious empowerment against enemies could perpetuate antisemitic stereotypes by linking Jewish identity with control over such outcomes, thereby targeting Jewish communities collectively. This aligns with IHRA's definition of antisemitism as it involves negative portrayals and potential stereotyping of Jews.
JDA_Explanation: The tweet refers to historical Jewish events, such as the Bani Nadir tribe and Quranic references, in a neutral and factual manner without targeting Jews for discrimination or hostility. It uses these examples to illustrate divine intervention rather than promoting antisemitic stereotypes or collective blame, thus not meeting the criteria for antisemitism according to JDA guidelines.

Text: "There is a global crisis of antisemitic hatred; a constant stream of attacks targeting Jews, their institutions & property."\n\n-- @antonioguterres calls for solidarity on Monday's #HolocaustRemembrance Day. https://t.co/kS02THL1Pa https://t.co/WtUjeudLIB
IHRA_Explanation: The tweet addresses the issue of antisemitism without targeting Jewish individuals or using harmful stereotypes. It raises awareness about the existence of antisemitism and promotes solidarity, aligning with efforts to combat hate rather than perpetuate it.
JDA_Explanation: The tweet addresses the issue of antisemitism by stating its existence and calling for solidarity on Holocaust Remembrance Day. It does not stereotype or blame Jews but rather highlights the reality of antisemitic attacks. This aligns with the JDA's recognition that addressing antisemitism is not inherently discriminatory, as it focuses on combating hatred rather than targeting Jewish people.

Text: Saw this but couldn‚Äôt get a photo, thanks. No one would believe it otherwise. The Nazi motto that branded Jews & others as ‚Äúparasites‚Äù feeding off the Volk, who would finally be made to work. Don‚Äôt want this future?Demand Trump Pence #OutNOW @RefuseFascism @jasonintrator https://t.co/xE7ZBbHVBp
IHRA_Explanation: The tweet references a Nazi motto used to dehumanize Jewish people, invoking historical antisemitic language. It targets Jewish individuals by associating them with parasitic behavior and compares current political figures to Nazi policies, aligning with IHRA's examples of contemporary antisemitism through the use of harmful stereotypes and rhetoric.
JDA_Explanation: The tweet explicitly references a Nazi motto that equates Jews with parasites, a well-known antisemitic stereotype. According to the JDA's guidelines, particularly guideline 2, this links Jews to evil forces, making it a direct example of antisemitic language. The mention of demanding Trump Pence may imply opposition to certain policies or leaders, but the central issue is the invocation of Nazi propaganda against Jews. This aligns with point 3, which identifies such statements as antisemitic. Thus, the tweet meets the criteria outlined in the JDA for antisemitism.

Text: (Acts 29:23164)  AND SO THE WHITE PEOPLE began calling themselves "WHITE JEWS" like today, that inhabit devil's murderous White Supremacist White Superiority Nazi Gestapo Hitler Israel of the Middle East, still demon Communist guided today, the WHITE JEWS impostor fraud people,
IHRA_Explanation: The tweet equates "White Jews" with a group linked to White Supremacy, Nazis, and Communism, using pejorative language that connects Jewish identity to harmful stereotypes and conspiracies. This aligns with IHRA's definition of antisemitism, which includes hateful rhetoric targeting Jewish individuals or communities.
JDA_Explanation: The tweet uses antisemitic language by equating "white Jews" with demonic imagery, White Supremacy, Nazis, andHitler. It applies classical antisemitic stereotypes by linking Jewish identity to evil forces and oppressive regimes. This aligns with the JDA's definition of antisemitism as discrimination against Jews based on their identity, using derogatory language and harmful stereotypes.

Text: #Peace will only happen with those countries that don‚Äôt wish to annihilate indigenous Jews from their Israeli homeland #bdsfail #morocco #israel https://t.co/x7LBu1yhTb
IHRA_Explanation: The tweet includes language that suggests a desire to annihilate indigenous Jews in Israel, which targets Jewish people based on their identity. This reflects antisemitic tropes by implying that some countries wish to eliminate Jews specifically, aligning with the IHRA definition of antisemitism as it involves hateful rhetoric towards Jews.
JDA_Explanation: The tweet suggests that peace can only be achieved by countries that do not wish to annihilate indigenous Jews in Israel. This statement implies a hostile attitude towards Jewish people, framed as a desire for their destruction, which aligns with antisemitic hostility as defined by the JDA. It indirectly attributes negative intentions to these countries based on their supposed wish to eliminate Jewish existence in Israel, falling under the category of hostility against Jews as a group.

Text: @Konnwatts @NightLord2009 @mcall Is there an example on this level? The post says Jews are not the real children of Israel and that they are extorting America.....
IHRA_Explanation: The tweet contains two elements that align with IHRA's definition of antisemitism. First, it claims "Jews are not the real children of Israel," which denies Jewish peoplehood and reflects antisemitic stereotypes about Jews being impostors or frauds regarding their connection to Israel. Second, it accuses Jews of "extorting America," suggesting a conspiracy where Jews unfairly take resources from the U.S., aligning with antisemitic narratives about Jewish conspiracies and control over societal institutions. These statements fit into IHRA's examples of antisemitism by targeting Jewish identity and societal roles with harmful stereotypes and conspiracy theories, contributing to a hostile environment towards Jews.
JDA_Explanation: The tweet asserts that "Jews are not the real children of Israel," which directly denies the right of Jews to exist and flourish in Israel as per guideline B.10. This aligns with antisemitism as defined by JDA, focusing on discrimination against Jews as a group. While the second part about "extorting America" may relate to stereotypes, the first statement is a clear example of antisemitic content.

Text: @atalantapendrag @JewishWonk Also, Jews have been mocked for their dietary laws for literal millennia. They're so easy to learn about people were able to spend the last multiple thousand years mocking them.
IHRA_Explanation: The tweet references the historical mockery of Jews' dietary laws, which aligns with antisemitic tropes as defined by IHRA. It uses stereotypes about Jewish religious practices and implies that Jews have been easy targets for such mockery over time. This falls under stereotyping, a key component of antisemitism, contributing to negative perceptions and thus qualifies as antisemitic.
JDA_Explanation: The tweet references the historical mockery of Jewish dietary laws and implies that Jews have been an easy target for such mockery over millennia. According to JDA guidelines (A.1), making sweeping generalizations about a population, particularly targeting them based on inherent characteristics like religious practices, can be considered antisemitic. This statement reflects prejudice against Jews by belittling their identity, aligning with the definition of antisemitism as discrimination or hostility against Jews as Jews. The historical context of such mockery is noted in classical antisemitic tropes, reinforcing the view that this tweet crosses into antisemitic territory.

Text: @realDonaldTrump Before ww 2 to broke hilter put propgranda out there on radio saying jews are  bad every weare you went that's all you here in Germany. same thing in america i here a wallmart radio there race injuon tv that white people are satan there a poltical agenda going
IHRA_Explanation: The tweet draws parallels between Nazi-era antisemitism and contemporary media in America, suggesting a negative portrayal of white people reminiscent of antisemitic tropes. It compares media content to Hitler's propaganda, using terms like "race injection TV" which echo negative stereotypes and imply a concerted effort to demean white individuals, aligning with IHRA's definition of antisemitism by invoking harmful stereotypes and historical comparisons.
JDA_Explanation: The tweet references Nazi propaganda against Jews and compares it to media in America targeting white people, drawing a parallel between antisemitic rhetoric and attacks on another group. This comparison can be seen as an indirect form of antisemitism, as it links negative stereotypes historically associated with Jewish communities to another group, potentially implicating Jews through association. The use of historical antisemitic tactics to attack another group constitutes antisemitism as defined by the JDA, which emphasizes that antisemitism can be both direct and indirect, even if not explicitly targeting Jews.

Text: @zainabsikander Does not Quran have this " It is duty of every muslim to kill jews Christians Kafirs and Apostates " perhaps sura 19 .Per my knowledge Mullahs in madrassa aredrilling this in children ...
IHRA_Explanation: The tweet references Quran verse 19 and states that Mullahs teach children that every Muslim must kill Jews, Christians, Kafirs, and Apostates. This directly incites violence against Jews and other groups, aligning with IHRA's definition of antisemitism, which includes hateful rhetoric targeting Jewish individuals or communities. By attributing a duty to harm non-Muslims, including Jews, the tweet promotes hatred and discrimination, fitting the antisemitic criteria.
JDA_Explanation: The tweet promotes a religious obligation to kill Jews, which is a clear manifestation of discrimination and hostility against Jews as a group. This aligns with the JDA's definition of antisemitism, particularly as it involves incitement to violence and collective responsibility for harm against Jews.

Text: @Boss_Life_TV @Eazydee1415 @Hemithetrackmom @Rob11784493 @beneficentking @tariqnasheed Are you joking? Literally all 3 definitions for the word "semitic" in the dictionary that *you* linked to refer to Jews.\n\nThis has to be one of the dumbest conversations I've ever been a part of. https://t.co/OKJv8XIHwP

JDA_Explanation: The tweet uses the term "semitic" in a way that links it to Jews, which aligns with the JDA guidelines by stereotyping and targeting Jewish people. It reflects antisemitic speech as defined, attacking based on Jewish identity.

Text: @Toa5t @fakehistoryhunt @GBMG19 @realDonaldTrump @nytimes Please tell us how jews were not drinking from wells but used fresh water (and please explain the difference) while living next to christian inhabitants in mediveal european cities.

JDA_Explanation: The tweet compares Jewish and Christian communities in medieval European cities regarding water use, potentially implying negative stereotypes about Jews having better access to resources than Christians. This comparison reinforces classical antisemitic notions of Jewish superiority or privilege over other religious groups, fitting under the JDA's definition of antisemitism as discrimination against Jews as Jews. The reference to historical context without specific evidence could further perpetuate harmful stereotypes, thus classifying the tweet as antisemitic.

Text: In 1938, Kristallnacht was a campaign of terror launched by the Nazis against the Jews & their businesses in Germany. \n\nIn the aftermath, the blame was put upon the Jews, resulting in a fine of $400 million & seizure of their properties to recover damage. https://t.co/cyB3NDiYNt
IHRA_Explanation: The tweet references Kristallnacht and describes how Jews were blamed for the events, leading to financial penalties. This places blame on a Jewish group, aligning with IHRA's example of antisemitism where collective responsibility is attributed to Jews for negative actions.
JDA_Explanation: The tweet references Kristallnacht and describes the aftermath by blaming Jews for financial repercussions, implying responsibility for events caused by the Nazis. This victim-blaming and reinforcement of negative stereotypes about Jews collectively being at fault aligns with antisemitic ideologies as defined by the JDA.

This aligns with IHRA's definition of antisemitism, which includes blaming Jews for societal issues and spreading harmful stereotypes. Text: Here is a question for the leadership candidates \n\n‚ÄúDo you condemn apartheid in Israel/Palestine, where Jews and Palestinians are granted different civil and human rights?‚Äù
IHRA_Explanation: The tweet suggests that Israel is practicing apartheid by granting different civil and human rights to Jews and Palestinians. This aligns with antisemitic tropes that target Jews as a collective, implying they are responsible for unequal treatment. By framing the issue in terms of Jewish actions or privileges, it reflects an antisemitic perception that can be harmful and discriminatory.
JDA_Explanation: The tweet suggests that there is a system of discrimination (apartheid) where Jews and Palestinians receive different civil and human rights. According to the JDA, applying classical antisemitic stereotypes or treating Jews as inherently linked to negative systems like apartheid can be considered antisemitic. This statement implies a disparity in rights based on identity, aligning with antisemitic discrimination against Jews as outlined in the guidelines.

Text: Bizarro history a la Rashida Tlaib @RashidaTlaib: "Arabs warmly welcomed Jews to the land after the Holocaust". \nSo wrong and not even close. Exactly the opposite. Arabs violently opposed Jewish immigration for decades, closing the door to Jews at their greatest hour of need.
IHRA_Explanation: The tweet corrects a misstatement about Arab reception of Jews post-Holocaust by providing accurate historical context regarding Arab opposition to Jewish immigration. It does not attack or stereotype Jews, instead focusing on factual history without antisemitic undertones. Thus, it doesn't align with IHRA's definition of antisemitism.
JDA_Explanation: The tweet provides a historical correction regarding Rashida Tlaib's statement about Jewish immigration after the Holocaust. It accurately points out that Arabs were not welcoming to Jewish immigrants during that time, correcting her claim. While the tweet is critical of Tlaib's statement and highlights Arab opposition to Jewish immigration, it does not engage in any antisemitic behavior as defined by the JDA. There is no evidence of discrimination against Jews, nor does it apply classical antisemitic stereotypes or hostilities. The content is a factual critique rather than an attack on Jewish people or their institutions. Thus, it does not meet the criteria for antisemitism under the JDA guidelines.

Text:
++ that resembled this ancient symbol for well being. This hooked cross was made the symbol of persecution of Jews, again.

Another white racist Christian misnamed this hooked cross as Swastika - because, we Hindus are a beastly people with a beastly religion.

That is how ++
IHRA_Explanation: The tweet uses the Swastika, an antisemitic symbol, to describe Hindus and their religion in a derogatory manner. This aligns with IHRA's definition of antisemitism, which includes using symbols to dehumanize or negatively characterize others, particularly in a religious context. By equating the Swastika with the persecution of Jews and then applying it to Hindus, the tweet promotes harmful stereotypes and hate speech against a non-Jewish group, thereby meeting the criteria for antisemitism.
JDA_Explanation: The tweet contains elements that violate the JDA definition of antisemitism. It associates a symbol (Swastika) with the persecution of Jews, aligning with classic antisemitic tropes as outlined in guidelines 2 and 3. Additionally, it uses derogatory language towards Hindus by labeling them as beastly, which falls under racial discrimination as per general guideline A. The tweet also employs sweeping negative generalizations about white Christians without specific context, reinforcing the JDA's concerns about such practices. Thus, the content qualifies as antisemitic and racist, violating the guidelines.

Text: @ToriGlass We didn't go to the moon. The economy will crash and the dollar will be worthless so they hoard items to trade (but not useful items!). We will have a civil war. We will have to smuggle Jews during the ww3 like Corrie Ten Boom...I could go on.
IHRA_Explanation: The tweet references smuggling Jews during a hypothetical World War III, drawing an analogy with Corrie Ten Boom, who was involved in hiding Jews during the Holocaust. This implies that Jewish individuals are being targeted or stigmatized, aligning with IHRA's definition of antisemitism, which includes behaviors targeting Jewish individuals and suggesting they need protection in a harmful manner. The mention of smuggling Jews constitutes a form of rhetoric that reflects negatively on Jewish identity, fitting within the contours of contemporary antisemitic tropes as outlined by IHRA.
JDA_Explanation: The tweet references smuggling Jews during a world war, which can imply that their presence requires hiding, suggesting negative stereotypes about Jews. This aligns with classic antisemitic tropes of associating Jews with secret power or needing to be hidden. While it mentions Corrie Ten Boom, a hero who helped Jews, the context of the tweet could be interpreted as stigmatizing Jews, fitting within the JDA's definition of antisemitism.

Text:
EXCLUSIVE: In a new national poll commissioned by @Ami_Magazine, 83% of Orthodox Jews say they're voting for President Trump, while 13% are voting for VP Biden.

This marks a 29% swing in favor of Trump since 2016.

See full poll results + analysis in the new issue of Ami. https://t.co/pqJl988jx5
IHRA_Explanation: The tweet reports on a poll regarding Orthodox Jews' voting preferences without any negative implications or stereotypes about Jewish people. It presents factual information about their political choices, which does not align with the IHRA definition of antisemitism, as it does not involve hate speech, conspiracy theories, or negative generalizations targeting Jews collectively.
JDA_Explanation: The tweet reports a poll result about Orthodox Jews' voting preferences without making any negative generalizations or linking them to harmful stereotypes. It reflects their political stance and doesn't involve antisemitic content, nor does it deny the Holocaust or promote conspiracies. Therefore, according to JDA guidelines, this tweet is not considered antisemitic.

Text:
International consensus has been wrong many times. Just because it‚Äôs popular doesn‚Äôt mean it‚Äôs correct.
For 2,000 years the world said the land of Israel doesn‚Äôt belong to the Jews.
They were wrong.
The world is wrong today when it says the Jews have no rights to Judea & Samaria.
IHRA_Explanation: The tweet does not align with IHRA's definition of antisemitism. It discusses historical and current perspectives on Jewish ownership of land, challenging past wrong consensus without targeting Jews or expressing hatred towards them. The content reflects political argumentation rather than antisemitic ideology as defined by IHRA.
JDA_Explanation: The tweet argues that historical and current international consensus denying Jews rights to Judea and Samaria is wrong, suggesting Jewish entitlement based on ethnicity. This assertion targets Jews collectively due to their ethnicity, aligning with antisemitic stereotypes about Jewish control over certain lands, as outlined in JDA guidelines B.10 and B.7.

Text: Crown Heights Assemblywoman, who has publicly castigated Jews for gentrification and sneeringly referred to Simcha Felder as ‚Äúthe Jewish senator,‚Äù defends Nick Cannon over his anti-Semitic podcast. https://t.co/zHoLy2Z6iC
IHRA_Explanation: The tweet uses derogatory language targeting Jewish individuals, such as referring to Simcha Felder in a sneering manner and criticizing Jews collectively for gentrification. This aligns with IHRA's definition of antisemitism, which includes blaming groups for societal issues and using demeaning language. Additionally, defending someone known for antisemitic remarks reinforces the antisemitic context.
JDA_Explanation: The tweet targets Jews by castigating them for specific actions (gentrification) and uses derogatory language ("sneeringly referred to Simcha Felder"), which aligns with guideline 3. Additionally, defending Nick Cannon's antisemitic podcast implies support for harmful statements against Jews, fitting into coded antisemitism under guideline 4. This behavior also reflects the denial of Jewish rights as per guideline B.10, contributing to antisemitic conduct.

Text: Just wanna say that Jews have been saying Richard Dawkins was dangerous for a long time. He has written about what we believe without ever consulting us. Any time I've said this I've been met with a resounding "ü§∑üèª‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è"\n\nSeeing a lot of takes excusing his "theological" work ü§∑üèª‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è
IHRA_Explanation: The tweet dismissively refers to Jewish criticism of Richard Dawkins' work by using an emoji that implies derision, suggesting that Jewish perspectives are being minimized. This dismissal can contribute to antisemitic stereotypes by undervaluing Jewish contributions and reinforcing the notion that their opinions are unwarranted or overly sensitive. Additionally, the mention of excusing Dawkins' theological work without consulting Jews may perpetuate the idea that non-Jewish voices hold greater authority over Jewish topics, which aligns with broader antisemitic tropes.
JDA_Explanation: The tweet does not exhibit antisemitism as defined by the JDA. It critiques Richard Dawkins' approach without using stereotypes or negative generalizations about Jews. There's no link to antisemitic concepts like conspiracy theories or evil associations. The content is a critique of Dawkins and his work, protected under free speech, without targeting Jews as a group.

Text: @joemcadam like I knew Silver Jews were gonna come out on top but I didn't have any fun doing it
IHRA_Explanation: The tweet refers to the band "Silver Jews," discussing their success without targeting Jewish individuals or using antisemitic language. There's no indication of negative stereotypes, conspiracies, or harm towards Jews, so it doesn't meet IHRA's definition of antisemitism.
JDA_Explanation: The tweet refers to the success of "Silver Jews," likely referencing the band led by Jewish artist David Simon. It expresses disappointment in their success not being enjoyable but does not involve any antisemitic content, stereotypes, or references to Jewish conspiracy theories. There's no indication of collective responsibility for Israel's actions, nor any coded language suggesting control over financial or political systems. The context is about the band's success, not targeting Jewish identity or Israel, thus not meeting JDA's criteria for antisemitism.

Text: @arabflop @Muqadaam They did not win the war. Israel begged them not to wage war, but they did. Btw "Palestinian" was referred to Jews before 1948&  Arabs were  just that arabs or Jordanian arabs. Just look at the Palestinian flag before 1948 there was none. Look up Israel flag before 1948
IHRA_Explanation: The tweet contains elements that align with antisemitic behavior as defined by IHRA. It refers to "Palestinian" as a term previously used for Jews before 1948, which distorts historical identity and can be seen as denying the Jewish heritage of the area. This manipulation of historical facts serves to delegitimize the existence of Palestinians, potentially reinforcing negative stereotypes about Jewish communities and their rights to self-determination. The tweet also questions Israel's actions in a way that could imply a lack of agency, contributing to a broader context of antisemitism by targeting Jewish identities and historical narratives.
JDA_Explanation: The tweet contains coded language that reflects antisemitic stereotypes by implying that the term "Palestinian" was historically used for Jews before 1948. This suggests a manipulation of identity and could be interpreted as downplaying the authenticity of Palestinian heritage, aligning with antisemitic tropes about Jewish conspiracies and identity manipulation. The reference to the absence of a Palestinian flag before 1948 further supports this coded language, indicating a possible attempt to question the legitimacy of Palestinian identity, which fits within the framework of antisemitic ideologies. Thus, the tweet adheres to the criteria outlined in the JDA guidelines for coded antisemitic speech.

Text: @lafcreative Truth! The sermon we watched today focused on Jeremiah 29, with the Jews in exile in Babylon, no return to normal in sight, and what they should be doing in that exile. I found it super helpful with current events, I‚Äôll send through a link when it gets uploaded!
IHRA_Explanation: The tweet refers to a sermon discussing Jeremiah 29, focusing on Jewish exile in Babylon and its relevance to current events. This is a historical biblical context, not an expression of hate or stereotype against Jews. There are no elements indicating antisemitism as defined by IHRA, such as blaming Jews for conspiracies, denying the Holocaust, or using derogatory symbols. The content appears to be about a religious discussion, not hate speech.
JDA_Explanation: The tweet does not exhibit any characteristics of antisemitism as defined by the JDA. It discusses a sermon on Jeremiah 29, focusing on the historical context of Jewish exile and its relevance to current events. There is no mention of Jews being targeted or Any negative stereotypes or conspiracy theories, nor does it imply collective responsibility or denial of rights. The content is interpretative, religious, and about current affairs, without any discriminatory language towards Jewish people.

Text: The roundup was aimed at foreign & "stateless" Jews, whose origin couldn't be determined, all aged from 16 to 50. There were to be exceptions for women "in advanced state of pregnancy" or breastfeeding, but "to save time, the sorting will be made at the first assembly centre". https://t.co/dW7nqKo8cN
IHRA_Explanation: The tweet references a historical event reminiscent of the Holocaust by describing a roundup targeting stateless Jews. It discusses sorting procedures and exceptions, which mirror Nazi policies. This context aligns with antisemitic tropes that dehumanize Jews through collective blame and normalization of atrocities, thereby violating IHRA's definition of antisemitism.
JDA_Explanation: The tweet refers to a historical roundup of foreign and stateless Jews, ages 16-50, with exceptions for pregnant women. This content evokes antisemitic stereotypes and resembles Nazi actions during the Holocaust, which is explicitly condemned in JDA guidelines. The reference to systematic treatment based on Jewish identity aligns with the definition of antisemitism as discrimination against Jews. Additionally, guideline 5 highlights that minimizing or denying the Holocaust is antisemitic, even if not explicitly stated. Thus, the tweet's content falls under antisemitic speech.

Text: How the Labour Party's witch-hunters target Jews who stand up for rights of Palestinians and oppose Israeli apartheid.  Read this excellent investigation. You won't find it in the Guardian or on the BBC.\nhttps://t.co/zbJu0OrQ3Z
IHRA_Explanation: The tweet contains language that aligns with antisemitic tropes by suggesting Jewish individuals are being unfairly targeted for opposing Israeli policies. It uses terms like "witch-hunters" to demean and falsely accuse these Jews of conspiracy or collective guilt, which fits the IHRA definition of antisemitism as it involves negative stereotypes and blaming a group for societal issues.
JDA_Explanation: The tweet violates the JDA definition of antisemitism by targeting Jewish individuals due to their political stance. It uses language that suggests a hostile intent towards Jews, framing them as unfairly targeted. This aligns with guidelines 7 and 4, which consider holding Jews collectively responsible for actions based on identity and coded speech that implies negative stereotypes or persecution. The use of terms like "witch-hunters" and dismissing media coverage can be seen as attempts to delegitimize criticism, thereby reinforcing antisemitic undertones.

Text: @Acosta trump just double down on calling immigrants rapists, criminals and low IQ‚Äôs - for the ones who may think he is speaking about undocumented immigrants - that‚Äôs how Hitler demonized the Jews, repeatly telling the good german people that the Jews, all of them, are vermin. https://t.co/cfmLE8GKGg
IHRA_Explanation: The tweet compares Trump's language about immigrants to Hitler's demonization of Jews, using harmful stereotypes. This mirrors classical antisemitic rhetoric by reducing a group to vermin and associating negative traits, aligning with IHRA's definition of antisemitism through dehumanization and harmful comparisons.
JDA_Explanation: The tweet compares Trump's criticism of immigrants to Hitler's demonization of Jews, which trivializes the Holocaust and spreads antisemitic rhetoric by linking a political argument to a historical atrocity. This analogy reduces severe historical atrocities to a political point, diminished the gravity of the Holocaust, and thus violates the JDA guidelines against antisemitism.

Text:

Instead, the tweet serves educational purposes on Holocaust Memorial Day.

It aims to honor historical memories and advocate for unity, aligning with principles of education and remembrance rather than discrimination.

Text: @DavidCornDC Paraphrasing Trump; it is not like these paintball shooters were trying to agitate the situation. I commend them for their restraint. Just like my fine people shouting Jews will not replace us.
IHRA_Explanation: The tweet uses the phrase "Jews will not replace us," which invokes a stereotype that Jews are conspiring to take over or replace others. This aligns with IHRA's definition of antisemitism, as it reflects a dehumanizing and stereotypical accusation against Jewish people, fitting into the category of blaming Jews collectively for societal issues or conspiracies. Therefore, the tweet is considered antisemitic.
JDA_Explanation: The tweet references "my fine people shouting Jews will not replace us," which utilizes a negative stereotype about Jews as a threatening group. According to the JDA, this type of statement is antisemitic as it fosters hostility by implying Jews are intruders or a threat, aligning with guidelines that prohibit such stigmatizing language.

Text:

The mention of Jews collectively controlling global events reflects a conspiratorial mindset that IHRA categorizes as antisemitic.

This narrative aligns with classical antisemitic stereotypes, promoting negative generalizations about Jews as a group. By suggesting such a delusion exists, it reinforces harmful stereotypes, making the content antisemitic as defined by JDA.

Text: @JackPosobiec NYC DeBlasio Defends Ban on Jews, Christians, Says BLM Protests OK Because of 'Profound Meaning'! Liberals are on the offensive to change the very way we live, do business or use our freedom of speech! Free thinkers have been banned! This is our future!\n\nhttps://t.co/NtOppGTb1l
IHRA_Explanation: The tweet specifically mentions "a ban on Jews," which directly targets Jewish individuals based on their religion. This aligns with IHRA's definition of antisemitism, which includes discriminatory actions against Jews. The reference to DeBlasio defending such a ban and the broader critique of liberals changing societal norms through restrictive policies further highlight the antisemitic nature by singling out Jewish people for exclusion.
JDA_Explanation: The tweet references a ban on Jews and Christians in NYC while contrasting it with the acceptability of BLM protests. This creates a comparison that could imply differential treatment, hinting at coded language or discrimination. The mention of free thinkers being banned evokes conspiracy-like themes, aligning with antisemitic stereotypes about certain groups influencing societal changes negatively. Thus, the tweet adheres to the JDA's criteria for antisemitism by invoking sweeping negative generalizations and potential coded language targeting specific groups.

Text:
@HeidiBachram @JoosyJew yes but there logic only applies if follow three facts are true and all arent,,,,,,,,
1 jews are white. ( most arent )
2 most jews in isreal are ashkanazis (not true)
3. most Ashkenazim are white (most cant pass as white )
IHRA_Explanation: The tweet contains statements that rely on harmful stereotypes about Jewish identity, such as suggesting Jews are white (except most) and that Ashkenazi Jews are typically white, which are deeply rooted in antisemitic tropes. These statements dehumanize and stereotype Jewish groups, aligning with IHRA's definition of antisemitism.
